{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3563626,"name":"Ben Edwards","username":"beedward","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/beedward/{size}/111315_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-20T23:27:40.786Z","cooked":"

Thought I’d put this out for teams attending the FIRST NC Pitt County event this weekend. We (the Gearcats) will be competing there, and I’m bringing my portable oscilloscope.
If any team needs help diagnosing a CANbus issue, come find team 6500, ask for Mr. Ben and hopefully we’ll figure it out.
Good luck out there

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":3,"updated_at":"2025-03-20T23:27:40.786Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":100,"readers_count":99,"score":70.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":496395,"topic_slug":"offering-can-help-at-fnc-pitt-county","display_username":"Ben Edwards","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":37435,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"EE mentor"},"post_url":"/t/offering-can-help-at-fnc-pitt-county/496395/1","custom_user_title":"EE mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3563633,"name":"CEF","username":"CEF","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/35a633/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-20T23:40:43.647Z","cooked":"

So, I’m not going to be at Pitt County, but I do have a portable oscilloscope. I’m curious what you do with a scope that helps with CANBus issues.

Right now, our MO is basically like this: connect one lead to one end of the yellow wire, connect the other lead to the other end, measure the resistance. If there’s minimal resistance, then do the same with the green. Then shake the CAN wires through the robot and wait for the resistance to change.

The most common issue is that there’s a break some place, so there is no connectivity. Then, it’s just a matter of divide-and-conquer.

Helps if you have a multimeter with a graph.

(Note: I am NOT a EE. Can barely spell EE.)

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":3,"updated_at":"2025-03-20T23:40:43.647Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":90,"readers_count":89,"score":23.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":496395,"topic_slug":"offering-can-help-at-fnc-pitt-county","display_username":"CEF","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":28649,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/offering-can-help-at-fnc-pitt-county/496395/2","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3563635,"name":"Ben Edwards","username":"beedward","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/beedward/{size}/111315_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-20T23:52:40.337Z","cooked":"

With a scope, you can see reflections and ringing that indicate termination issues or excessive stub length (stub length is really more of a problem for CAN FD, given the size of bus we’re dealing with).
You can also see differences in signaling from message to message. If some CAN packets look clean (recessive about 2.5v, dominant with CANH at ~4v and CANL at ~1v) and others have flipped levels, offsets, or movement on only CANH or CANL, you can tell what kind of bus issue exists - so you can look for open connections, shorts to the frame, or swaps between CANH and CANL.
I’ve seen several cases where CANH and CANL got swapped twice - using the multimeter method everything looked fine but several motor controllers wouldn’t talk.
A scope is kind of a multimeter with a graph… just a really fast one that can see transients.

More advanced scopes than mine have the tools to decode the CAN message format and look for individual bit errors, CRC errors, and other protocol problems. Those tend to be useful more for people designing CAN controllers.
